title: Confusion reigns at World Masters as fake names, redraw and resignation create 'shambles'
text:
The Circus Tavern will host the next stages of the World Masters (Photo by Ian Walton/Getty Images)

The British Darts Organisation (BDO) is going through a turbulent time and the opening day of the World Masters seemed to optimise the chaos and confusion that is damaging the organisation’s already shaky reputation.

The World Masters has been running since 1974 and remains one of the most prestigious events in the sport, won by a host of legends, from Eric Bristow, to Phil Taylor to Michael van Gerwen.

It is second only to the World Championship in the BDO calendar, but scenes on Wednesday in Grays were not befitting of an event of the stature of the World Masters, some suggesting that an average local darts tournament is better organised.

The Weekly Dartscast was at the scene which was described as optimistic at first, with only minor quibbles over the size of the venue – 32 boards for over 200 players seeming too small.

Advertisement

Advertisement

However, things quickly turned to farce as BDO chairman Des Jacklin took to the stage and explained that the advertised format was wrong, but more importantly, that a number of international players in the venue, who had qualified for the event, were not registered to play (not realising they had to do so and pay a £20 fee).

‘Because this is a new way of registering for the Masters there have been countries that have turned up today that did not register’ said Jacklin. ‘We have allowed for this, those names will be put into the draw.

‘Wherever possible, the people who have not turned up to play will be switched with the people that have, that didn’t know.

‘It is not their fault, they did not know that they had to register and we can’t have people travelling between three and 10 hour flights to get here and then find they cannot play. It is the first year this has happened and it will not happen again.’

This seemed reasonable, as Jacklin was right that a number of qualified players had not turned up for the event, including seeds Nick Kenny and Wayne Warren.

However, the non-registered players didn’t equal the non-arrivals so it wasn’t as simple as the original plan, then came the mystery of the fake players in the draw.

Advertisement

Advertisement

For reasons this observer does not fully understand, non-existent players were put in the draw, apparently so they could be replaced with real players if too many turned up.

What would have happened if someone would have had to take on a man who doesn’t exist is not clear.

This never came to pass, though, because the draw, which was made on Tuesday was scrapped and a redraw commenced at the venue.

Due to several internationally-based players having travelled without correctly entering this year's World Masters, there has been a redraw. Link for the updated Men's @one80 @LstyleEurope World Masters draw can be found here 👇👇👇 https://t.co/DIXbtoi3Xm — BDO Darts (@BDOdarts) October 23, 2019

This came after a heated meeting with the top 16 players and the BDO top brass, in which Jacklin told the players that he was going to step aside as chairman after the January World Championship at The O2.

One of the top 16 players confirmed this to Metro.co.uk, saying: ‘He did say he was done after the O2.’

When asked for further details on the day in Grays, the same player added: ‘All I do know is it was a complete shambles!’

The redraw was made, amidst an angry room, with The Weekly Dartcast saying, ‘I’ve never seen a hall turn that way.’

The redraw made the tournament somewhat chaotic as players did not have the card system telling them when and where they should be and information was given out over a microphone, which was far from clear.

Advertisement

There were also no chalkers (scorers) assigned to boards and volunteers were called for, which caused further delay to starts on some boards.

They are calling out the draw on mic. I can barely hear. Also…there are no chalkers allocated for any boards so I suspect a further delay incoming. #WorldMasters pic.twitter.com/krbUyjP69f — The Darting Nerd (@thedartingnerd) October 23, 2019

There was further mystery earlier in the day when a contract was produced for players to sign, which materialised on Twitter from Live Darts’ content machine Phill Barrs.

If signed, the contract stated that playing in the World Masters or BDO World Championship qualifiers would mean players could not play in the PDC World Championship or qualifiers in December.

If players went on to play in the PDC event, their prize money from the World Masters would not be paid, or if it had been paid, would be owed back to the BDO.

This wouldn’t apply to many players, but some it would very much impact, with American Danny Baggish and Slovenia’s Benjamin Pratnemer who have already qualified for the PDC World Championship and were also in the World Masters, in Grays, ready to play.

Baggish did not sign the contract and played anyway, losing to Gary Stone in the last 64. It is unconfirmed whether the Slovenian signed the contract, but he is into the last 32 and playing Carl Hamilton at the Circus Tavern on Friday.

The contract handed to players at the World Masters (Picture: Twitter/Phill Barrs)

Another major issue is that the prize fund for the tournament was still not confirmed on the morning the event got underway.

Advertisement

It is now believed to have stayed at the same level as last season (£60,000) but that has not been officially announced, and players were understandably unsettled to be arriving at a competition without knowing what they were playing for.

A competitor was told on Wednesday: ‘We’ll tell you if you get to the last 32, if you don’t make that, you don’t need to know.’

There were also minor bones of contention, which would have seemed minimal on other days, but surrounded by other bizarre events, they just added to the chaos.

Brian Cathcart, a player from Northern Ireland, was named on the draw sheet at the end of the day, apparently coming through three rounds to book his spot in the last 32.

Cathcart had never been at the venue. This was a simple error on the sheet, and it was Pratnemer who had come through that section of the draw, but with the confusion swirling, it would have been almost no surprise to see the no-show still succeed.

When the darts actually started and the tournament was played down to 32 players, it largely went without much fuss and we have our last 32, who will compete at the legendary Circus Tavern on Eurosport on Friday.

That 32 will not include the likes of Wesley Harms, Jim Williams, Martin Adams and Andy Hamilton, though, who all fell early on Wednesday. The top 16 seeds all had to begin at the very first stage, which was another kick in the teeth for them, and does hurt the star power of the televised stages.

All fans, players and organisers alike will be hoping the rest of the tournament goes much more smoothly and the chaos of Grays will be forgotten, but it all just seemed a great shame for those who had worked so hard to qualify, and some who had travelled so far to be there.

The Weekly Dartscast’s Matthew Kiernan said: ‘It’s a big deal – 21 people were there from Northern Ireland, three or four of them got to the last 32 which is great, but it’s the pinnacle of their season. They were all really sad and furious at the redraw, they are the ones shouting in the video.

‘There was a big group from America, one of them, Timmy Nicoll, had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer four months ago, because of the diagnosis he decided to go to the event and took his son who qualified for the youth as well, and they’re treated like that. It was tough and heartbreaking.’
